Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in assessing Ojo's residence in Canada under the Citizenship Act
Outcome: Application for judicial review granted; decision quashed
Evidence_Type: Residence history, duration of absences from Canada (675 days)
Legal_Provision: Sections 22.1 and 22.2 of the Citizenship Act
Basis_of_Claim: Incorrect application of residence threshold and premature use of Koo test
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Absence from Canada for 675 days; failure to assess statutory residence requirement before applying Koo test
Application_Error: Skipped mandatory residence threshold assessment; assumed incorrect period of residence
Assessment_Standard: Residence requirement under Citizenship Act followed by Koo test if applicable
Evidence_Ignored: Actual duration and pattern of absences from Canada
Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied by Federal Court
Application_Factor: Koo test factors: centralization of mode of existence in Canada
Decision_Outcome: Remanded to Minister for reconsideration or referral to a new Citizenship Judge

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false statements in relation to citizenship application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Unreasonable assessment of evidence and misapplication of qualitative test for residency
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's credibility undermined by incomplete disclosure and contradictory evidence
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: False statements affecting residency qualification
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to address material absences and inconsistencies
Crimes.Application_Error: Incomplete disclosure of absences and financial activity
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Qualitative test for residency (centralization of life in Canada)
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard in administrative decision-making
Crimes.Application_Factor: Residency compliance through physical presence or centralization
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision found unreasonable; case remitted to Minister for redetermination
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False or misleading information in citizenship application

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation regarding residency for citizenship purposes
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Unreasonable assessment of evidence and misapplication of Koo’s qualitative test for residency
Crimes.Governing_Law: Citizenship Act, Koo v. Canada precedent
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubts due to undeclared trips and implausible explanations
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Residency requirement under section 5 of Citizenship Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Misrepresentation of factual basis for residency
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to assess whether applicant centralized life in Canada
Crimes.Application_Error: Omission of material travel history
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Koo’s qualitative test for residency
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonable justification required for residency determination
Crimes.Application_Factor: Pattern of absences and financial ties abroad
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Error in credibility and legal test application; remanded for reconsideration
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Inaccurate representation of residency in application

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose material information in citizenship application
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 5(1) of the Citizenship Act – Residency requirement
Crimes.Governing_Law: Citizenship Act, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to report absences, provided inconsistent credit card explanations, possible undisclosed passports
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Questioned due to unreported absences and foreign activity
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Omission of relevant travel and financial information
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documentation supporting claimed residency
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Serious doubts due to incomplete disclosures
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision; remitted to Minister for reassessment
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Remittal to Minister for proper evaluation
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Speculative assumptions and inadequate analysis rendered decision unreasonable
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possibly using a minor to commit fraud (credit card misuse)
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Credit card misuse and potential fraud
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of accepting implausible explanation for unauthorized transactions
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Failure to investigate child’s capacity to make international purchases
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Judge’s acceptance of explanation deemed unreasonable
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to justify unusual financial activity
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Explanations must be credible and consistent with known facts
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Potential fraud involving minor and misuse of financial instruments
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing and location of credit card transactions abroad
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRAC method applied in judicial review
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Attributed transactions to minor child without corroborating evidence
Crimes.Outcome: Case remitted to Minister for redetermination
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 122 of Criminal Code (fraud), Citizenship Act misrepresentation clauses

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of citizenship judge's assessment of residency
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Judge accepted Pereira's explanation despite memory issues and lack of corroboration
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Residency requirement under Citizenship Act (1095 days in 4 years or strong attachment)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to report six trips abroad
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of corroborating evidence and significant discrepancies in travel history
Crimes.Application_Error: Misrepresentation of absences from Canada
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness, transparency, and intelligibility
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Absence of passport records and trip documentation
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Applicant must prove physical presence or strong attachment to Canada
Crimes.Application_Factor: Travel history and credibility of applicant
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Unreasonable decision; overturned on judicial review

Crimes.Application_Facts: Pereira failed to report six trips abroad and provided weak explanations
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Omission of travel history affecting residency calculation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Insufficient inquiry by citizenship judge despite discrepancies
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over citizenship decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of supporting documents for travel claims
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Weak explanations accepted without scrutiny
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Quashing of decision and proper reassessment
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Judge failed to require credible evidence despite red flags
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Citizenship judge, reviewed by Federal Court

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical residency requirement
Legal_Provision_Violated: Residency requirement under the Citizenship Act – three out of four years (1,095 days)
Application_Facts: Dr. Udwadia was physically present in Canada for only 717 days during the four-year period preceding the application
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship judge failed to determine when residence was established; applied subjective test incorrectly
Evidence_Used: Record of Dr. Udwadia's physical presence in Canada (717 days)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of analysis on establishment of residence despite insufficient physical presence
Outcome: Dr. Udwadia must reapply for citizenship
Relief_Sought: Minister sought judicial review and overturning of citizenship grant
Legal_Standard_Applied: Two-step test for residency: (1) establishment of residence in Canada, (2) minimum 1,095 days of physical presence
Decision_Rationale: The citizenship judge’s decision was unreasonable because Dr. Udwadia did not meet the statutory residency requirement and the judge failed to properly apply the legal test

Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical residency requirement
Application_Facts: Koo was physically present in Canada for only 232 days within the four-year period preceding his application; maintained business interests in Hong Kong; made frequent visits to Canada but did not establish it as his primary residence
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from a decision of a Citizenship Judge
Evidence_Used: Record of physical presence, travel history, ties to Hong Kong, nature and frequency of visits to Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of established residence in Canada
Legal_Standard_Applied: Three years (1095 days) of accumulated residence in Canada within four years prior to application under s. 5(1)(c)
Decision_Rationale: Koo did not meet the statutory residency requirement; Canada was not his primary residence; temporary visits insufficient to satisfy residency obligation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to meet residency requirements for citizenship
Crimes.Application_Facts: Respondents spent less than 50% of their time in Canada due to business-related absences; physical presence fell short of required 1,095 days within four years
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet minimum 3-year physical presence requirement
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge failed to properly apply the Koo test
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Business success and international travel records
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of meaningful ties to Canada under Koo criteria
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of application by a different Citizenship Judge
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Koo test for assessing residency in absence of full physical presence
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Judge improperly substituted business justifications for actual physical attachment to Canada; ignored key Koo factors

Crimes.Violation_Type: False or misleading representation regarding residency
Crimes.Application_Facts: Respondents spent less than 50% of time in Canada; significant absences for business; only two of six Koo factors favored residency claim
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Applications approved despite clear failure to meet residency obligations, implying inaccurate assessment of facts
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Improper application of Koo test by Citizenship Judge
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Travel history, business activities abroad, limited connections to Canada
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documentation demonstrating strong residential ties to Canada
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Reassessment by a new Citizenship Judge
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Koo test for qualitative assessment of residency
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Judge unreasonably prioritized business needs over statutory residency requirements and established Koo criteria

Application_Facts: PRRA Officer designated under delegation instruments to act under s. 25(1) of IRPA
Claimant_Status: Zolotareva sought permanent residence on humanitarian grounds
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review application filed in Federal Court
Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether PRRA Officer had authority under s. 25(1) of IRPA
Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of PRRA Officer's decision
Decision_Rationale: PRRA Officer had jurisdiction; decision lawful and reasonable

Legal_Issue: Authority of PRRA Officer, natural justice, child's best interests
Credibility_Assessment: No credibility issue found; child’s interests considered
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Child's best interests weighed but not determinative
Application_Error: Alleged breach of natural justice and misapplication of child's best interests
Decision_Outcome: PRRA Officer acted within jurisdiction and decision upheld

Application_Facts: Chang was absent for 875 days during the four-year period; maintained significant ties to Taiwan
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet physical presence requirement
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship judge failed to consider all relevant evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Judge ignored evidence of significant ties to Taiwan
Decision_Rationale: Chang's extensive absences and dual life pattern between Canada and Taiwan undermined continuous residency claim

Crimes.Crime_Name: Deception to obtain a student visa
Legal_Issue: Was the Board's decision to draw a negative inference from the applicant's use of deception to gain a student visa reasonable?
Governing_Law: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Outcome: The judicial review was allowed, and the case was remitted to a different panel for reconsideration.
Credibility_Assessment: The Board drew a negative inference from the applicant's deception, questioning her credibility.
Evidence_Type: Inconsistencies and deception in obtaining a visa
Legal_Provision: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Use of deception to obtain a student visa
Application_Error: Failure to address the sur place claim
Evidence_Ignored: Sur place claim based on events in Canada
Decision_Outcome: Set aside and remitted for redetermination
Document_Fraud: Use of deceptive information in student visa application

Crime_Name: Administrative Error in Visa Application Process
Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer correctly applied s. 78(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations in assessing Mr. Marr's educational credentials
Governing_Law: Section 78(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Outcome: The officer erred by failing to consider special circumstances under s. 78(4); decision set aside and application remitted for reconsideration
Evidence_Type: Educational credential, duration of study, information on Scotland’s education system
Legal_Provision: s. 78(4), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient points awarded due to misapplication of regulations regarding educational credentials
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Officer failed to consider special circumstances such as shorter education system in Scotland
Decision_Maker: Visa officer, later reviewed by Federal Court
Application_Error: Incorrect point allocation (15 instead of 20) for educational credential
Evidence_Ignored: Potential relevance of Scotland’s shorter post-secondary education system
Application_Factor: Two-year post-secondary credential with 13 years of study (not meeting 14-year threshold)
Decision_Outcome: Application refused initially; decision quashed and remitted for re-evaluation

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to demonstrate intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, SOR/2002-227
Crimes.Application_Facts: Nguyen, a Vietnamese citizen, had a nine-month absence from his Vietnamese business and expressed intent to stay in Canada with his children.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national applying for a work permit
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to prove compliance with temporary residency requirements
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review assessed reasonableness of visa officer's decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Applicant's ties to Vietnam, duration of absence from business, statements about family in Canada
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of strong evidence showing intent to return to Vietnam
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Nguyen's claim of intent to return was weakened by prolonged absence and desire to remain with children
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn refusal and grant work permit
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Proof of intention to leave Canada at the end of authorized stay
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Tribunal reasonably concluded Nguyen did not prove he would leave Canada after his authorized stay

Crimes.Evidence_Type: Business ownership in Vietnam, duration of absence, familial connections in Canada
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Regulation 200(1)(b) – Requirement to prove intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Applicant failed to meet regulatory requirement to demonstrate intent to depart Canada
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Weak ties to home country and expressed intent to remain in Canada
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide sufficient evidence of intent to leave Canada

Crimes.Legal_Standard: Proof required under Regulation 200(1)(b)
Crimes.Application_Factor: Duration of absence from Vietnamese business and presence of children in Canada

Legal_Issue: Does the applicant qualify for a stay of removal based on humanitarian and compassionate grounds?
Evidence_Type: Medical records, evidence of financial hardship, family ties, country condition reports
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Irreparable harm, best interests of the child, balance of convenience
Application_Error: Officer allegedly ignored hardships and failed to consider best interests of the child
Assessment_Standard: Serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Evidence_Ignored: Hardships related to medical condition, financial dependence on compensation, family ties in Canada
Legal_Standard: Test for granting a stay under H&C provisions
Application_Factor: Injuries preventing employment, risk of losing medical care and compensation, unsafe conditions in Nigeria

Violation_Type: Removal order following overstayed temporary resident status
Application_Facts: Applicant remained in Canada after visa expiration, refugee claim and H&C applications denied
Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant, permanent resident applicant under H&C
Procedural_Issue: Seeking stay of removal during judicial review
Evidence_Used: Proof of injury, inability to work, family ties, financial hardship
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Alleged failure by officer to consider key humanitarian factors
Remedy_Sought: Interim relief from removal based on H&C grounds
Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Decision_Rationale: Risk of financial ruin, lack of medical care in Nigeria, best interests of child not considered
Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency, Immigration Division

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Violation_Type: Failure to depart after final removal order
Application_Facts: Refugee claim, PRRA, and H&C applications all rejected; remains in Canada post-removal order
Claimant_Status: Failed refugee claimant, removal order issued
Procedural_Issue: Application for stay of removal during judicial review
Evidence_Used: Medical condition, financial dependency, family ties, country risk in Nigeria
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer allegedly misapplied H&C test and ignored stepson's best interests
Outcome: Removal stayed until legal proceedings conclude
Remedy_Sought: Interim protection from removal based on humanitarian grounds
Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Decision_Rationale: Risk of harm in Nigeria, loss of medical treatment, financial collapse, family separation

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed her visa since 1995, made a false refugee claim in 2005, and applied for humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) grounds in 2010
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Foreign national without valid immigration status
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Made a false refugee claim in 2005
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Application for H&C consideration under IRPA
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether applicant must apply for permanent residence from outside Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Family support in Haiti, lack of substantial ties in Canada
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence of personal hardship or risk upon return to Haiti
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative – due to past false refugee claim and lack of credible hardship claims
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent resident status on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn officer's decision and grant H&C permanent residency
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Unusual or disproportionate hardship under Section 25(1) IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded no unusual or disproportionate hardship would occur upon departure; applicant has family support in Haiti and weak ties to Canada

Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None identified – officer considered all relevant factors
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decision
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of non-compliance and fraud weighed heavily

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the applicant excluded due to serious criminality based on use of forged passport and false identity?

Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Serious criminality based on document fraud
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Maximum penalty vs. actual sentencing range and mitigating circumstances

Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Presumptively serious if max penalty ≥10 years, but must consider full context
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Possibility of summary conviction and applicant’s motive to flee persecution
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Supreme Court guidelines on seriousness assessment
Crimes.Application_Factor: Nature of offense, mode of prosecution, penalties, and individual circumstances

Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Seriousness determined by max penalty (≥10 years) and contextual factors
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Potential for summary conviction (6 months) and flight from persecution
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Supreme Court precedent requiring holistic seriousness assessment
Crimes.Application_Factor: Elements of crime, prosecution mode, penalties, and surrounding circumstances

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Actions linked to escape from persecution, affecting moral culpability

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed 1,204 days of presence but had 1,092 days of absence in India; lack of corroborating evidence for addresses and family presence in Canada
Misrepresentation_Element: Potential misrepresentation due to insufficient evidence supporting residency claims
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of documentation to verify Canadian addresses and family residence
Credibility_Assessment: Citizenship Judge found applicant's claims not sufficiently supported
Legal_Standard_Applied: Three years of physical or qualitative residence within four years prior to application
Decision_Rationale: Insufficient evidence to prove compliance with residency requirement under subsection 5(1)(c)

Application_Facts: Discrepancies in the applicant's testimony were attributed to translation problems between Yoruba and Igbo interpreters.
Procedural_Issue: RPD failed to consider translation issues when assessing credibility.
Evidence_Used: Testimony of the applicant, interpreter services (Yoruba and Igbo)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD did not address potential translation errors despite explanations from the applicant.
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant not credible due to contradictions without considering translation issues; assessment deemed unreasonable.
Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by a differently constituted RPD
Decision_Rationale: Failure to consider translation issues rendered credibility assessment unreasonable.

Application_Facts: Applicants sought judicial review after their PRRA application was rejected due to insufficient evidence of persecution.
Procedural_Issue: The applicants argued biased treatment of 'interested parties' evidence but failed to show unreasonable assessment.
Credibility_Assessment: Officer found no sufficient evidence of religious persecution; applicants' credibility arguments dismissed as not demonstrating unreasonableness
Decision_Rationale: The officer evaluated documents, considered country conditions, and found no sufficient evidence of religious persecution. No errors warranting intervention were found.

Credibility: Panel member's demonstrated impartiality over time and in past decisions
Legal_Provision: Principle of objective appearance of impartiality in administrative and judicial decision-making
State_Protection_Adequacy: Adequate, as proper legal test was applied and upheld on review
Risk_Nature: Procedural fairness and perception of bias
Perpetrator_Entity: Panel member (Mr. La Salle) accused of bias
Victim_Basis: Claimant before the panel alleging unfair treatment

Violation_Type: Refusal of refugee status based on credibility and evidence assessment
Legal_Provision_Violated: Imputed political opinion, membership in a particular social group
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution due to imputed political opinion and social group membership
Procedural_Issue: Allegation of erroneous finding of fact or misinterpretation of evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board found applicant's claim implausible; preference given to documentary evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Board assessed applicant's testimony as lacking credibility
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of Board's negative refugee determination
Legal_Standard_Applied: Plausibility of claim, risk of persecution
Decision_Rationale: Board's decision supported by credible evidence; no misinterpretation or capricious error found
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility in refugee claim due to use of fraudulent documents and inconsistent statements
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Refugee Protection Division decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Use of fake U.S. passport, inconsistencies in testimony, past criminal conviction for fraud
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Cumulative inconsistencies and fraudulent document use undermined credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Standard of proof for refugee claims is on a balance of probabilities; credibility issues can lead to dismissal
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Applicant's lack of credibility based on misrepresentation and contradictions
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to failure to meet burden of proof
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Fraudulent passport, inconsistent employment and political involvement claims
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicant provided inconsistent and implausible explanations
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certification of question of law or quashing of decision
Crimes.Authority: Federal Court upholding Refugee Protection Division decision

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adverse credibility finding based on inconsistencies and implausibilities
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Numerous contradictions and implausible elements in testimony
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial inconsistencies, fraudulent passport, changing marital status
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Seeking refugee protection based on alleged persecution
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Cumulative inconsistencies and misrepresentations
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Refugee Protection Division, reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Application_Error: Inconsistent statements about political appointment and employment
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of credibility determination
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None noted – Board considered all relevant evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard of proof: balance of probabilities
Crimes.Application_Factor: Implausibility of rapid political appointment while hiding

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility challenged due to discrepancies and implausible testimony
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Multiple contradictions in story including political involvement and employment
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution due to political opinion
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Cumulative credibility issues including forged entry documents
Crimes.Application_Error: Conflicting accounts of political activities and concealment
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Balance of probabilities with reasonableness review
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No indication of ignored evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Credibility assessed on totality of evidence
Crimes.Application_Factor: Implausible explanation for political exposure while in hiding
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Fraudulent entry into Canada using forged documents

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility assessment based on inconsistencies and implausibilities
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Numerous discrepancies in testimony including political role and employment
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refugee protection based on political opinion
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Cumulative inconsistencies and use of fraudulent documents
Crimes.Application_Error: Contradictory statements about hiding and public political roles

Crimes.Application_Factor: Use of fraudulent passport and implausible timeline
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of fraudulent travel documents to enter Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making false statements to obtain benefit under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of credibility findings
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Found inconsistencies in testimony, lack of corroboration, and implausibilities
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence, lack of corroborative documentation
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged persecution due to sexual orientation
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility of applicant's testimony
Crimes.Application_Error: Inconsistent statements over time
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard (justification, transparency, intelligibility)
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Claimant's ability to demonstrate need for protection

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of refugee claim decision
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution based on sexual orientation in U.S. Army
Crimes.Legal_Framework: International refugee law, domestic immigration law
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Denial of refugee protection by IRB
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Adequate remedies available within U.S. military system
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Fear of punishment due to desertion and sexual orientation
Crimes.Credibility: Contradictions in testimony and lack of evidence
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Presumption of state protection not rebutted

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with military duty
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: U.S. Uniform Code of Military Justice
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant failed to meet military duties and sought refugee status in Canada
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Irrelevant – claim based on fear of return
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistent claims about treatment and options in U.S. military
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Canadian assessment of foreign military conduct
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of corroborating evidence for alleged persecution
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistent testimony and implausible narrative
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: US capable of providing adequate protection; alternative remedies available
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board, Federal Court

Evidence_Assessment: Possibility of rehabilitation vs. proof of rehabilitation
Decision_Outcome: Deportation order upheld initially, then set aside
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate possibility of rehabilitation
Key_Evidence_Considered: Post-conviction conduct, including cessation of alcohol abuse and compliance with supervision
Defendant_Response: Demonstrated personal reform and rehabilitation efforts
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; case remitted for re-determination by another tribunal
Legal_Provision: Section related to serious criminality and inadmissibility under IRPA
